sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: During our ongoing studies of fungal diversity on leaf litter, two exciting species were collected from Thailand . Morphological examination coupled with phylogenetic analyses revealed that our species belongs to Paramicrothyrium and Tumidispora in Microthyriaceae . Maximum likelihood, maximum parsimony, and Bayesian analyses of combined internal transcribed spacer (ITS) and large nuclear subunit ribosomal DNA ( LSU ) sequence data were performed to clarify the phylogenetic affinities of the species. Based on their distinctive morphological traits and phylogenetic support, the new species Paramicrothyrium bambusae and Tumidispora thailandica were introduced. In addition, the new species were compared with phylogenetically and morphologically closely related species, and detailed descriptions, micrographs, and phylogenetic trees of the new species are provided.
Keywords : 2 new species, Bambusa vulgaris , Dimocarpus longan , epiphytes, Microthyriales , new taxa, taxonomy, Thailand

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Fungal foliar epiphytes are an enthralling group of species that mainly occur on the surface of plant leaves (
Wu et al . 2011
,
Hyde et al . 2013
,
Hongsanan et al . 2016
,
Chethana et al . 2021
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022a
, b). They are polyphyletic and ubiquitous, and most belong to Ascomycetes (
Chomnunti et al . 2011
,
Hongsanan et al . 2016
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022a
). Foliar epiphytes occur as black mildews, black dots, and sooty molds which belong to Asterinales , Capnodiales , Microthyriales , Parmulariales , and Zeloasperisporiales in Dothideomycetes , Eurotiomycetes , Lecanoromycetes, and Meliolales in Sordariomycetes (
Crous et al . 2009
,
Hyde et al . 2013
,
Chomnunti et al . 2011
, 2014,
Hongsanan et al . 2016
,
Chethana et al . 2021
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022b
). The nutritional modes of foliar epiphytes vary and include saprobes, plant parasites, fungal parasites, and lichens ( Carroll 1991 , Gilbert & Reynolds 2002 , 2005 ,
Hongsanan et al . 2016
,
Chethana et al . 2021
). However, most foliar epiphytes are obligate parasites that can harm host plants by invading host cells for nutrition intake (
Wu et al . 2011
,
Chethana et al . 2021
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022b
). In some species, the covering of hyphae on the surface of the plant might cause marketability issues (
Chomnunti et al . 2014
,
Hyde et al . 2018
). Even though the taxonomic history of foliar epiphytes is vast and has been studied extensively for decades, there are still countless unidentified species ( Dickinson & Preece 1976 , Blakeman 1981 , Fokkema & van den Heuvel 1986 , Carroll 1991 ,
Wu et al . 2011
,
Hyde et al . 2013
,
Chomnunti et al . 2014
,
Hongsanan et al . 2014
, 2017 ,
Marasinghe et al . 2022b
). In addition, there are still many taxonomic ambiguities in foliar epiphytes because many species have been identified solely by their morphological characteristics ( Ryan1924 , Luttrell 1973 , von Arx & M̧ller 1975, Barr 1987 ). Therefore, DNA-based molecular phylogeny can be used to address these taxonomic issues of foliar epiphytes. However, the majority of foliar epiphytic species are still lacking DNA molecular data in public databases because most are obligate parasites and difficult to culture in artificial media ( i . e ., PDA , MEA) (
Chomnunti et al . 2014
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022b
).

Microthyriales contain foliar epiphytes, which was established by Arnaud in (1918) to place Microthyriaceae . The species are mostly biotrophs and saprotrophs, usually found on leaves, stems, or fruits (
Hongsanan et al . 2014
,
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). Based on morphology coupled with phylogeny, this order currently contains the single family Microthyriaceae (
Hongsanan et al . 2020
,
Wijayawardene et al . 2022
). With the sexual genus Microthyrium providing as the type genus, Saccardo (1883) established the Microthyriaceae . This family members have superficial, flattened thyriothecia, parallelly arranged upper wall cells, central ostiole, poorly developed lower peridium, obclavate to cylindrical-clavate asci, and hyaline to brown ascospores (
Wu et al . 2011
,
Hyde et al . 2013
,
Hongsanan et al . 2014
,
Qiao et al . 2021
).
Hongsanan et al . (2020)
accepted 11 genera in Microthyriaceae (three asexual genera and eight sexual genera). Recently, five additional genera (Asexual morphs) have been introduced to Microthyriaceae , such as Antidactylaria , Isthmomyces (
Qiao et al . 2021
)
, Nothoanungitopsis (
Crous et al . 2021
)
and Keqinzhangia , Pseudocoronospora (
Zheng et al . 2022
)
. Thus, 16 genera are accepted in Microthyriaceae , viz . Antidactylaria , Arnaudiella , Calothyriopsis , Chaetothyriothecium , Hamatispora , Isthmomyces , Keqinzhangia , Microthyrium , Neoanungitea , Nothoanungitopsis , Paramicrothyrium , Pseudocoronospora , Pseudomicrothyrium , Pseudopenidiella , Seynesiella , and Tumidispora (
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). Among these, Microthyrium is the most diverse genus (91 species), and other genera have less than five species, such as Calothyriopsis (4), Chaetothyriothecium (1), Hamatispora (1), Keqinzhangia (1), Neoanungitea (2), Paramicrothyrium (1), Pseudocoronospora (1), Pseudomicrothyrium (1), Pseudopenidiella (3), Seynesiella (5), and Tumidispora (1) (
Hongsanan et al . 2020
,
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
).

Two intriguing fungal species were collected from Thailand as part of our ongoing research on the diversity of fungi on litter substrates in the tropics. Their taxonomic positions were established through morphological descriptions combined with phylogenetic analyses.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Samples collection, morphological studies and isolation

Leaf litter samples ( Bambusa vulgaris and Dimocarpus longan ) were collected from Chiang Mai province , Thailand . All the collected samples were taken back to the university and examined with a stereo-microscope (AXIOSKOP 2 PLUS Series). Squash mount preparations were prepared to determine fungal microscopic features (e.g., asci, ascospores, conidia, and pseudoparaphyses). All the images were captured by using an OLYMPUS SZ61 compound microscope equipped with a Canon AXIO-CAM 506 COLOR digital camera. Lactoglycerol and nail polish were used to prepare the permanent slides. All the photo plates were prepared using Adobe Photoshop CS3 Extended version 10.0 software (Adobe Systems, USA ) and measurements were taken using ZEN2 (blue edition).

The isolation process described by
Senanayake et al . (2020)
was used for single spore isolation. Potato dextrose agar ( PDA ) was used to transfer germinated spores, which were then incubated at 25 ° C . Following that, careful subculturing was carried out to obtain pure cultures. After four weeks of time duration, culture characteristics (on PDA ) were observed. All the type specimens were deposited in the herbariums of Mae Fah Luang University ( MFLU ) and National Chiayi University ( NCYU ). Living cultures were deposited in the Culture Collection of Sustainable Development of Biological Resources Laboratory (SDBR), Faculty of Science, Chiang Mai University. Numbers for Faces of Fungi and Index Fungorum were obtained as described in
Jayasiri et al . (2015)
and Index Fungorum (2022) .

sec.title: DNA extraction and PCR amplification
sec.p: The thermal cycle program for LSU and ITS genes amplification was as follows; initially 95 ° C for 3 mins, followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 95 ° C for 30 secs, annealing at 55 ° C for 50 secs, elongation at 72 ° C for 30 sec and final extension at 72 ° C for 10 mins. Agarose gel electrophoresis (1%) stained with ethidium bromide was used to check the quality of PCR products. PCR products were purified and sequenced by Shanghai Sangon Biological Engineering Technology & Services Co., Ltd, China . Nucleotide sequences were deposited in GenBank ( TABLE 1 ).

sec.title: Sequence alignment and phylogenetic analyses
sec.p:
A combined data set of LSU and ITS genes and a total of 45 isolates were used for the phylogenetic analyses. The newly attained sequences were initially subjected to BLASTn searches in GenBank (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) to identify the taxa that shared the most similarities with our strains. The additional sequences included in the analysis were from recent publications (
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). The Kirschsteiniothelia lignicola ( MFLUCC 10-0036) was selected as the out-group taxon. Both forward and reverse sequences were assembled using SeqMan v. 7.0.0 (DNASTAR, Madison, WI). Single-gene datasets and multi-gene datasets were aligned with MAFFT ( Katoh & Standley 2013 , http://mafft.cbrc.jp/alignment/server/;2016) and manually improved with BioEdit v.7.2.5 ( Hall 2004 ). The CIPRES Science Gateway platform (
Miller et al . 2010
) was used to create the maximum likelihood tree using the GTR+I+G model of evolution and RAxML-HPC2 on XSEDE (8.2.8) (
Stamatakis et al . 2008
, Stamatakis, 2014 ). PAUP (Phylogenetic Analysis Using Parsimony) version 4.0b10 was used for Maximum parsimony analysis ( MP ) ( Swofford 2002 ). Tree Length (TL), Consistency Index (CI), Retention Index (RI), Relative Consistency Index (RC) and Homoplasy Index (HI) were calculated (Parsimony descriptive tree statistics). MrModeltest v.3.7 (
Posada et al . 1998
) was carried out to check the evolutionary models for phylogenetic analyses under the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC). MrBayes v. 3.1.2 (Huelsenbeck and Ronqvist, 2001) was used for Bayesian analysis (Rannala and Yang, 1996, Zhaxybayeva and Gogarten, 2002). Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method was used to estimate the posterior probability, Markov chains were run for 3,000,000 generations (standard deviation of split frequencies less than 0.01) and trees were sampled every 100 th generation (printfreq=100). In total, 30, 000 trees were resulted and the first 20% of trees were discarded (burn-in phase of the analyses), while the remaining 80% of trees were used for calculating posterior probabilities in the majority rule consensus tree. The FigTree v1.4.0 ( Rambaut, 2012 ) program was used to view the phylogeny trees and reorganized by using Microsoft PowerPoint (2010). Sequences derived in this study were deposited in GenBank ( TABLE 1 ).

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Wu et al . (2011)
established this as a monotypic genus to include Paramicrothyrium chinensis , which has irregular ostioles without a darkened ring. Currently, only the type is available in Paramicrothyrium ( Index Fungorum 2022 )
. In this study, we introduce Paramicrothyrium bambusae sp. nov. from dead leaves of Bambusa vulgaris .
Etymology :—Name reflects the host genus Bambusa .

Epiphytic on the upper surface of dead leaves of Bambusa vulgaris Schrad.
( Poaceae ), visible as small black dots. Sexual morph : Undetermined. Asexual morph : Thyriothecia 90–120 × 100–130 μm ( x = 110 × 112 µm, n = 10), solitary, scattered, superficial, flattened, circular, dark brown to black, easily be removed from the substrate, poorly developed basal layer, with irregular, central ostiole, dark brown, irregularly rounded at the margin. Upper wall comprises brown cells of textura angularis , radiating in irregular, parallel lines from center to the outer rim. Conidiogenous cells evanescent. Conidia 3–4 × 1–2 µm ( x= 3.7 × 1.2 μm, n = 30), hyaline, cylindrical with obtuse ends, unicellular, minute guttulate, straight or slightly curved, smooth-walled.

Culture characteristics :— Colonies on PDA, 10–12 mm diam. after 4 weeks at 25 °C, colonies from above: medium dense, circular, raised, cottony, surface smooth, entire margin, white to cream at margin, white at center; reverse: white to yellowish at margin, light brown at center. Mycelium white to cream with tufting.

Material examined :— Thailand , Chiang Mai , dead leaves of Bambusa vulgaris ( Poaceae ), 28 September 2018 , D.S. Tennakoon, ADS046A (MFLU 19-2729, holotype ); ex-type living culture, SDBR-CMU436. ibid . 29 September 2019 , ADS046B (NCYU 19-0085, paratype ); ex-paratype living culture, SDBR-CMU437.
GenBank numbers :—MFLU 19-2729: ITS: ON751741 ; NCYU 19-0085: ITS: ON751742 .

Ariyawansa et al . (2015)
introduced Tumidispora to include the generic typeT . shoreae , which was isolated from Shorea species
in Thailand . Tumidispora has brown to dark brown thyriothecia, with a prominent darkened area around the central ostiole, fissitunicate, cylindrical to cylindric-clavate, short pedicellate asci and 1–2-seriate, hyaline, 1-septate ascospores (constricted at the septum) with an apical swollen cell (
Ariyawansa et al . 2015
). There is currently only the type species in this genus ( Index Fungorum 2022 ). In this study, we introduce T . thailandica sp . nov .
from Dimocarpus longan in Thailand .
Etymology :—The specific epithet “ thailandica ” refer to the country in which the fungus was first collected

Epiphytic on the upper surface of dead leaves of Dimocarpus longan Lour.
( Sapindaceae ), visible as small black dots. Superficial hyphae absent. Sexual morph : Thyriothecia 200–260 × 210–280 μm ( x = 230 × 240 µm, n = 10), solitary, superficial, scattered, flattened, circular, brown to black, easily be removed from the substrate, poorly developed basal layer, with prominent, darker, central ostiole, darker around the ostiole, dark brown towards the outer lighter rim, irregularly rounded at the margin. Upper wall containing brown cells of textura angularis , radiating in slightly irregular, parallel lines from center to the outer rim. Hamathecium containing 2 μm wide, branched pseudoparaphyses. Asci 40–46 × 5–7 μm ( x = 45 × 6 µm, n = 20), 8-spored, fissitunicate, bitunicate, short pedicellate, cylindrical to cylindric-clavate, apically rounded, with an ocular chamber. Ascospores 9–11 × 3–4 μm ( x = 10.5 × 3.5 µm, n = 10), 1–2-seriate, hyaline, fusiform, rounded ends, 1-septate, constricted at the septum, apical cell swollen and wider, basal cell sub-conical, guttulate, two appendages in upper cell, smooth-walled. Asexual morph : Undetermined.

Culture characteristics :— Colonies on PDA, 18–22 mm diam. after 4 weeks at 25 °C, colonies from above: medium dense, circular, raised, surface smooth, entire margin, light green at margin, dark grey to brown at centre; reverse: light brown to light green at margin, dark grey to black at centre. Mycelium dark grey to black with tufting.

Material examined :— Thailand , Chiang Mai , dead leaves of Dimocarpus longan ( Sapindaceae ), 25 April 2018 , D.S. Tennakoon, DHAY021A (MFLU 19-2771, holotype ); ex-type living culture, SDBR-CMU438. ibid . 28 April 2018 , DHAY021B (NCYU 19-0090, paratype ); ex-paratype living culture, SDBR-CMU439.
GenBank numbers :—MFLU 19-2771: LSU: ON751750 ; ITS: ON751739 ; NCYU 19-0090: LSU: ON751751 ; ITS: ON751740 .

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
In recent years, there have been several revisions made to the taxonomy of the Microthyriaceae . Initially, Saccardo (1883) established this family to accommodate nine genera and was solely based on morphological characteristics, such as flattened, superficial thyriothecia, parallel arrangement of upper wall cells, obclavate to cylindrical-clavate, bitunicate asci and uni- to multi-septate, hyaline to brown ascospores. Subsequently, this family was placed in various orders, viz . Hemisphaeriales ( Theissen 1913 , Luttrell 1973 ), Microthyriales ( Arnaud 1918 )
, Dothideales (M̧ller & von Arx 1962 ) and, Melanommatales ( Barr 1987 )
. In addition,
Kirk et al . (2008)
annotated this family in Microthyriales and Lumbsch & Huhndorf (2010) placed Microthyriaceae in Dothideomycetes families incertae cedis . However, most of those studies have suffered from phenotypic plasticity, which has led to misinterpretations and subjected to various taxonomic confusions as many species are known only from their morphological characteristics ( Doidge 1942 , M̧ller & von Arx 1962 , Luttrell 1973 , Barr 1987 , Hofmann 2010 ). But, in the last two decades morphology combined with molecular data has emerged as the primary research tool for Microthyriaceae species identification, thus taxonomic placements of this family have made significant progress. For example, the findings of
Wu et al . (2011)
, which provided a broad revision of Microthyriaceae based on morphology and molecular data, helped to clear up a lot of ambiguities in the family.
Wu et al . (2011)
findings have been followed by numerous subsequent studies, most of which have used multi-gene phylogeny for their phylogeny analyses (
Hongsanan et al . 2014
,
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). Recent investigations have identified a number of new genera in Microthyriaceae , thus this family is currently phylogenetically highly diversified. For example,
Qiao et al . (2021)
introduced two aquatic hyphomycetes genera ( Antidactylaria and Isthmomyces ) from China and Nothoanungitopsis by
Crous et al . (2021)
from South Africa . In addition,
Zheng et al . (2022)
introduced another two aquatic hyphomycetes genera from China ( Keqinzhangia and Pseudocoronospora ) based on morphology and phylogeny evidence.

Tropical, subtropical, and temperate climates all include a variety of Microthyriaceae species (M̧ller & von Arx 1962 , Luttrell 1973 , Barr 1987 ,
Wu et al . 2011
,
Hongsanan et al . 2020
,
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). However, despite the fact that Microthyriaceae species have been found all over the world, most of them lack DNA molecular data. For instance, only five Microthyrium species
have molecular data, out of the 91 Microthyrium species
listed in Index Fungorum (2022) . In addition, DNA molecular data not available for some genera, such as Arnaudiella , Calothyriopsis and Seynesiella (
Hongsanan et al . 2020
)
. Therefore, it is vital to gather representative species of these genera and collect DNA data to clarify their phylogenetic relationships. In this study, we provide taxonomic details for two new species in Paramicrothyrium and Tumidispora based on both morphology and phylogeny. Both species were collected from dead leaves in Thailand .
